topic.title: HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade 2.0: Deploying the Tahoe Template

body.p: After the lifecycle manager is installed, the next task in installing the Tahoe deployment is to deploy the HP Helion OpenStack cloud and install the HPE Distributed Cloud Networking (DCN) components.

If you are installing the Tahoe deployment, which includes the KVM region and uses HPE DCN VRS networking, follow these instructions. If you are installing a different deployment, disregard these instructions.

ol.li:
Execute the following command to provision and configure the HPE Helion OpenStack cloud. hlm define -t tahoe <cloudname>
Where:: <cloudname> is the name of the cloud to create.
The command creates the /var/hlm/clouds/<cloudname> directory, which contains several JSON template files.

section.title: Configure the back-end drivers
section.p: Configure the back-end drivers to enable management of the OpenStack Block Storage volumes on HPE StoreVirtual VSA and/or HPE StoreServ (3PAR) storage arrays. The HPE Block Storage (Cinder) service allows you to configure multiple storage back-ends. A sample file provides all the variables needed to use VSA and/or 3PAR attached to the KVM region. You need to edit this file for your environment and save as cinder_conf.
Use the following steps to configure back-end support:

ol.li: Change to the /cinder/blocks directory: cd /var/hlm/clouds/<cloudname>/services/cinder/blocks Where <cloudname> is the name you assigned to the cloud. The directory contains several sample Cinder configuration files that you can edit, depending upon which storage method(s) you are using.

Edit the cinder_conf.multiBackendSample file.
Use the enabled_backends variable to list each of the back-ends you are using.
Region/Hypervisor Volume Backend Backend Name
KVM 3PAR hp3par
KVM VSA hplefthand
You can use either 3PAR and VSA in the KVM region or select both if you have respective storage arrays
Note: The HP 3PAR Web Services API server must be enabled and running on the HP 3PAR storage system. For more information, see the OpenStack documentation at: Enable the HP 3PAR Fibre Channel and iSCSI drivers.
A typical configuration file that enables both VSA and 3PAR back-ends appears similar to the following example:[DEFAULT] enabled_backends=hp3par, hplefthand ...
[hp3par] volume_backend_name=<mybackendname1> hp3par_api_url=https://<management_ip>:8080/api/v1 hp3par_username=<username> hp3par_password=<password> hp3par_cpg=<cpg> san_ip=<san_ip> san_login=<username> san_password=<password> hp3par_iscsi_ips=<iscsi_target_ips seperated by ,> volume_driver=cinder.volume.drivers.san.hp.hp_3par_iscsi.HP3PARISCSIDriver hp3par_debug=False hp3par_iscsi_chap_enabled=false hp3par_snapshot_retention=48 hp3par_snapshot_expiration=72
[hplefthand] volume_backend_name=<mybackendname2> hplefthand_username = <username> hplefthand_password = <password> hplefthand_clustername = <Cluster Name> hplefthand_api_url = https://<Iscsi Virtual IP address>/lhos volume_driver = cinder.volume.drivers.san.hp.hp_lefthand_iscsi.HPLeftHandISCSIDriver hplefthand_debug = false
